article_title: Downregulation of Mpl Marks the Transition to Lymphoid-Primed Multipotent Progenitors with Gradual Loss of Granulocyte-Monocyte Potential.
abstract_text: Evidence for a novel route of adult hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) lineage commitment through Lin − Sca-1 + Kit + Flt3 hi (LSKFlt3 hi ) lymphoid-primed multipotent progenitors (LMPPs) with granulocyte/monocyte (GM) and lymphoid but little or no megakaryocyte/erythroid (MkE) potential was recently challenged, as LSKFlt3 hi cells were reported to possess MkE potential. Herein residual MkE potential segregated almost entirely with LSKFlt3 hi cells expressing the thrombopoietin receptor (Thpor), whereas LSKFlt3 hi Thpor − LMPPs lacked significant MkE potential in vitro and in vivo, but sustained combined GM and lymphoid potentials, and co-expressed GM and lymphoid but not MkE transcriptional lineage programs. Gradually increased transcriptional lymphoid priming in single LMPPs from Rag1 GFP mice was shown to occur in the presence of maintained GM lineage priming, but gradually reduced GM lineage potential. These functional and molecular findings reinforce the existence of GM-lymphoid progenitors with dramatically downregulated probability for committing towards MkE fates, and support that lineage restriction occurs through gradual rather than abrupt changes in specific lineage potentials.
